clues: Home to a famous clock tower that is often mistaken for its bell.
A royal family resides in this city, attracting millions of visitors each year.
fun_fact: Big Ben refers to the bell, not the tower itself! The tower is called Elizabeth Tower.
London has over 170 museums, making it a paradise for history lovers.
trivia: The London Underground is the oldest metro system in the world.
London was the first city to have traffic lights, installed in 1868.

clues: This city is home to an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
Nicknamed the 'Eternal City' for its long history and timeless charm.
fun_fact: The Colosseum could hold up to 50,000 spectators in ancient times.
Rome has a country within its borders—Vatican City, the smallest country in the world.
trivia: Ancient Romans used urine to wash their clothes, believing in its cleaning power.
The Pantheon in Rome has the largest unreinforced concrete dome in the world.

clues: Home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.

trivia: Egyptians invented one of the earliest forms of writing—hieroglyphics.
The Sphinx originally had a nose, but it was destroyed over time.
